if paragraph (a) does not apply in his case but he was detained in a hospital in England and is sent on discharge by that hospital to an area in England, for that area; or
in any other case

P2para.Text: After that subsection insert—

Section 40 of the Care Act 2013 applies to a dispute about where a person was ordinarily resident for the purposes of subsection (3)(a) above as it applies to a dispute about where a person was ordinarily resident for the purposes of Part 1 of that Act.
After subsection (4) insert—
In this section, “after-care services” means services which have both of the following purposes—

P3para.Text: meeting a need arising from or related to the mental disorder of the person concerned; and
reducing the risk of a deterioration of the person’s mental condition (and, accordingly, to reduce the risk of the person requiring admission to a hospital again for treatment for the disorder).

P2para.Text: After section 117 of that Act insert—
The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that where—

P3para.Text: the local social services authority under section 117 is, in discharging its duty under subsection (2) of that section, providing or arranging for the provision of accommodation for the person concerned;
the person concerned expresses a preference for particular accommodation; and
any prescribed conditions are met,

P2para.Text: the local social services authority must provide or arrange for the provision of the person’s preferred accommodation.
Regulations under this section may provide for the person concerned, or a person of a prescribed description, to pay for some or all of the additional cost in prescribed cases.

In subsection (2), “additional cost” means the cost of providing or arranging for the provision of the person’s preferred accommodation less the amount that the local social services authority would expect to be the usual cost of providing or arranging for the provision of accommodation of that kind.
The power to make regulations under this section—

P3para.Text: is exercisable only in relation to local social services authorities in England;
includes power to make different provision for different cases or areas.

P2para.Text: The ways in which a local authority may discharge its duty under section 117 of the Mental Health Act 1983 include by making direct payments; and for that purpose Schedule 4 (which includes modifications of the provisions of this Part relating to direct payments) has effect.

In the case of a person who, immediately before the commencement of subsections (3) and (4), is being provided with after-care services under section 117 of the Mental Health Act 1983, the amendments made by those subsections do not apply while those services are continuing to be provided to that person.

P1group.Title: Prisoners and persons in approved premises etc.

P2para.Text: In its application to an adult who is detained in prison, this Part has effect as if references to being ordinarily resident in an area were references to being detained in prison in that area.

In its application to an adult who is residing in approved premises, this Part has effect as if references to being ordinarily resident in an area were references to being resident in approved premises in that area.

In its application to an adult who is residing in any other premises because a requirement to do so has been imposed on the adult as a condition of the grant of bail in criminal proceedings, this Part has effect as if references to being ordinarily resident in an area were references to being resident in premises in that area for that reason.

The power under section 30 (preference for particular accommodation) may not be exercised in the case of an adult who is detained in prison or residing in approved premises except for the purpose of making provision with respect to accommodation for the adult—

P3para.Text: on his or her release from prison (including temporary release), or
on ceasing to reside in approved premises.

P2para.Text: Sections 31 to 33 (direct payments) do not apply in the case of an adult who, having been convicted of an offence, is—

P3para.Text: detained in prison, or
residing in approved premises.

P2para.Text: Sections 37 and 38 (continuity of care), in their application to an adult who is detained in prison or residing in approved premises, also apply where it is decided that the adult is to be detained in prison, or is to reside in approved premises, in the area of another local authority; and accordingly—

P3para.Text: references to the adult’s intention to move are to be read as references to that decision, and
references to carers are to be ignored.

P2para.Text: Sections 42 and 47 (safeguarding: enquiry by local authority and protection of property) do not apply in the case of an adult who is—

P3para.Text: detained in prison, or
residing in approved premises.

P2para.Text: An SAB’s objective under section 43(2) does not include helping and protecting adults who are detained in prison or residing in approved premises; but an SAB may nonetheless provide advice or assistance to any person for the purpose of helping and protecting such adults in its area in cases of the kind described in section 42(1) (adults with needs for care and support who are at risk of abuse or neglect).
Section 44 (safeguarding adults reviews) does not apply to any case involving an adult in so far as the case relates to any period during which the adult was—

P3para.Text: detained in prison, or
residing in approved premises.

P2para.Text: Regulations under paragraph 1(1)(d) of Schedule 2 (membership of Safeguarding Adults Boards) may not specify the governor, director or controller of a prison or a prison officer or prisoner custody officer.
“Prison” has the same meaning as in the Prison Act 1952 (see section 53(1) of that Act); and—

P3para.Text: a reference to a prison includes a reference to a young offender institution, secure training centre or secure children’s home,

the reference in subsection (10) to the governor, director or controller of a prison includes a reference to the governor, director or controller of a young offender institution, to the governor, director or monitor of a secure training centre and to the manager of a secure children’s home, and

the reference in that subsection to a prison officer or prisoner custody officer includes a reference to a prison officer or prisoner custody officer at a young offender institution, to an officer or custody officer at a secure training centre and to a member of staff at a secure children’s home.

P2para.Text: “Approved premises” has the meaning given in section 13 of the Offender Management Act 2007.
“Bail in criminal proceedings” has the meaning given in section 1 of the Bail Act 1976.
For the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: a person who is temporarily absent from prison is to be treated as detained in prison for the period of absence;
a person who is temporarily absent from approved premises is to be treated as residing in approved premises for the period of absence;

a person who is temporarily absent from other premises in which the person is required to reside as a condition of the grant of bail in criminal proceedings is to be treated as residing in the premises for the period of absence.

P1group.Title: Registers of sight-impaired adults, disabled adults, etc.

P2para.Text: A local authority must establish and maintain a register of sight-impaired and severely sight-impaired adults who are ordinarily resident in its area.
Regulations may specify descriptions of persons who are, or are not, to be treated as being sight-impaired or severely sight-impaired for the purposes of this section.

A local authority may establish and maintain one or more registers of adults to whom subsection (4) applies, and who are ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, for the purposes in particular of—

P3para.Text: planning the provision by the authority of services to meet needs for care and support, and
monitoring changes over time in the number of adults in the authority’s area with needs for care and support and the types of needs they have.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies to an adult who—

P3para.Text: has a disability,
has a physical or mental impairment which is not a disability but which gives rise, or which the authority considers may in the future give rise, to needs for care and support, or

comes within any other category of persons the authority considers appropriate to include in a register of persons who have, or the authority considers may in the future have, needs for care and support.

P2para.Text: “Disability” has the meaning given by section 6 of the Equality Act 2010.
A local authority must act under the general guidance of the Secretary of State in the exercise of functions given to it by this Part or by regulations under this Part.
Before issuing any guidance for the purposes of subsection (1), the Secretary of State must consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
A local authority may authorise a person to exercise on its behalf a function it has under—

P3para.Text: this Part or regulations under this Part (but see subsection (2)), or
section 117 of the Mental Health Act 1983 (after-care services).

P2para.Text: The references in subsection (1)(a) to this Part do not include a reference to—

P3para.Text: section 3 (promoting integration with health services etc.),
sections 6 and 7 (co-operating),
section 14 (charges),
sections 31 to 33 (making direct payments),
sections 42 to 47 (safeguarding adults at risk of abuse or neglect), or
this section.

P2para.Text: An authorisation under this section may authorise an employee of the authorised person to exercise the function to which the authorisation relates; and for that purpose, where the authorised person is a body corporate, “employee” includes a director or officer of the body.
An authorisation under this section may authorise the exercise of the function to which it relates—

P3para.Text: either wholly or to the extent specified in the authorisation;
either generally or in cases, circumstances or areas so specified;
either unconditionally or subject to conditions so specified.

P2para.Text: An authorisation under this section—

P3para.Text: is for the period specified in the authorisation;
may be revoked by the local authority;

P2para.Text: A care provider of a specified description commits an offence if—

P3para.Text: it supplies, publishes or otherwise makes available information of a specified description,
the supply, publication or making available by other means of information of that description is required under an enactment or other legal obligation, and
the information is false or misleading in a material respect.

P2para.Text: But it is a defence for a care provider to prove that it took all reasonable steps and exercised all due diligence to prevent the provision of false or misleading information as mentioned in subsection (1).
“Care provider” means—

P3para.Text: a public body which exercises functions in connection with the provision of health services or adult social care in England, or

a body (other than a public body) which provides health services or adult social care in England pursuant to arrangements made with a public body exercising functions in connection with the provision of such services or care.

P2para.Text: “Health services” means services which must or may be provided as part of the health service.
“Adult social care”—

P3para.Text: includes all forms of personal care and other practical assistance for individuals who, by reason of age, illness, disability, pregnancy, childbirth, dependence on alcohol or drugs, or any other similar circumstances, are in need of such care or other assistance, but

does not include anything provided by an establishment or agency for which Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Education, Children’s Services and Skills is the registration authority under section 5 of the Care Standards Act 2000.

P2para.Text: “Specified” means specified in regulations.

If a care provider commits an offence under either of the provisions mentioned in subsection (8) in respect of the provision of information, the provision of that information by that provider does not also constitute an offence under subsection (1).
The provisions referred to in subsection (7) are—

P3para.Text: section 44 of the Competition Act 1998 (provision of false or misleading information) as applied by section 72 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 (functions of the OFT under Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998 to be concurrent functions of Monitor), and

section 117 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (provision of false or misleading information) as applied by section 73 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 (functions of the OFT under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to be concurrent functions of Monitor).

P2para.Text: If a care provider commits an offence under subsection (1) in respect of the provision of information, the provision of that information by that provider does not also constitute an offence under section 64 of the Health and Social Care Act 2008 (failure to comply with request to provide information).
A care provider who is guilty of an offence under section 84 is liable, on summary conviction or on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

A court before which a care provider is convicted of an offence under section 84 may (whether instead of or as well as imposing a fine under subsection (1)) make either or both of the following orders—

P3para.Text: a remedial order,
a publicity order.

P2para.Text: A “remedial order” is an order requiring the care provider to take specified steps to remedy one or more of the following—

P3para.Text: the conduct specified in section 84(1),
any matter that appears to the court to have resulted from the conduct,
any deficiency, as regards the management of information, in the care provider’s policies, systems or practices of which the conduct appears to the court to be an indication.

P2para.Text: A “publicity order” is an order requiring the care provider to publicise in a specified manner—

P3para.Text: the fact that it has been convicted of an offence under section 84,
specified particulars of the offence,
the amount of any fine imposed, and
the terms of any remedial order made.

P2para.Text: A remedial order may be made only on an application by the prosecution specifying the terms of the proposed order; and any such order must be on such terms (whether those proposed or others) as the court considers appropriate having regard to any representations made, and any evidence adduced, in relation to that matter by the prosecution or on behalf of the care provider.
A remedial order must specify a period within which the steps referred to in subsection (3) are to be taken.
A publicity order must specify a period within which the requirements referred to in subsection (4) are to be complied with.
A care provider that fails to comply with a remedial order or a publicity order commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine.
There is to be a body corporate called Health Education England (referred to in this Act as “HEE”).
Schedule 5 (which includes provision about HEE’s constitution, the exercise of its functions and its financial and reporting duties) has effect.

P1group.Title: Planning education and training for health care workers etc.

impose on HEE a duty to perform the duty as it applies as a result of provision made under paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: Regulations may provide that the duty under subsection (1) or a duty imposed under subsection (2) may only be performed, or may not be performed, in relation to persons of a specified description.

section 13M (duty on National Health Service Commissioning Board to support that system);
section 14Z (duty on clinical commissioning groups to support that system).

P2para.Text: Regulations may give HEE further functions relating to education and training for health care workers.
HEE may, with the consent of the Secretary of State, carry out other activities relating to—

the provision of information and advice on careers in the health service.

P2para.Text: After section 63(6) of the Health Services and Public Health Act 1968 insert—
The Secretary of State may make such other payments as the Secretary of State considers appropriate to persons availing themselves of such instruction in England.

The Secretary of State may make a payment under subsection (6)(b) or (6A) subject to such terms and conditions as the Secretary of State decides; and the Secretary of State’s power to make such a payment includes power to suspend or terminate the payment, or to require repayment, in such circumstances as the Secretary of State decides.

“Health care workers” means persons in relation to whom HEE’s duty under section 1F(1) of the National Health Service Act 2006 is to be performed.

P1group.Title: Ensuring sufficient skilled health care workers for the health service

P2para.Text: HEE must exercise its functions with a view to ensuring that a sufficient number of persons with the skills and training to work as health care workers for the purposes of the health service is available to do so throughout England.
Regulations may provide that the duty under subsection (1) may only be performed, or may not be performed, in relation to persons of a specified description.

P1group.Title: Quality improvement in education and training, etc.

P2para.Text: HEE must exercise its functions with a view to securing continuous improvement—

P3para.Text: in the quality of education and training provided for health care workers;
in the quality of health services.

P2para.Text: HEE must, in exercising its functions, promote—

P3para.Text: research into matters relating to such of the activities listed in section 63(2) of the Health Services and Public Health Act 1968 (social care services, primary care services and other health services) as are relevant to HEE’s functions, and

P2para.Text: In section 2(2) of the Health Act 2009 (bodies required to have regard to NHS Constitution when exercising health service functions), after paragraph (g) insert—

P3para.Text: Health Education England.

P2para.Text: HEE must exercise its functions with a view to securing that education and training for health care workers is provided in a way which promotes the NHS Constitution.
“Health services” means health services provided as part of the health service.
“NHS Constitution” has the meaning given by section 1(1) of the Health Act 2009.

The Secretary of State must publish before the start of each financial year a document which specifies the objectives and priorities that the Secretary of State has set for HEE for that year in relation to the education and training to be provided for health care workers.
The Secretary of State must also publish at intervals of not more than three years a document (called the “Education Outcomes Framework”) which
specifies the outcomes that the Secretary of State has set for HEE to achieve having regard to those objectives and priorities.
The Secretary of State—

P3para.Text: may revise a document published under subsection (1) or (2), and
if the Secretary of State does so, must publish it as revised.

P2para.Text: HEE must publish a document which—

P3para.Text: specifies the objectives and priorities that it has set, for the period specified in the document, for the planning and delivery of education and training to health care workers,
specifies the outcomes that HEE expects to achieve in that respect during that period having regard to those objectives and priorities, and
includes, or refers to a document which includes, guidance for LETBs (see section 93) on the exercise of the function under section 97(1).

P2para.Text: In performing the duty under subsection (4), HEE must have regard, in particular, to its objectives in the longer term in relation to the planning and delivery of education and training to health care workers.

A document under subsection (4) may specify different periods in relation to different categories of health care worker.
HEE must, before the end of 12 months beginning with the date on which a document under subsection (4) is published—

P3para.Text: review the document, and,
if HEE revises it, publish it as revised.

P2para.Text: HEE may perform the duty under subsection (4) by publishing two or more documents which, taken together, comply with that subsection.

P3para.Text: the likely future demand for health services and for persons with the skills and training to work as health care workers for the purposes of the health service,
the sustainability of the supply of persons with the skills and training to work as such,
the priorities that providers of health services have for the education and training of persons wishing to work as such,
the mandate published under section 13A of the National Health Service Act 2006,
the objectives of the Secretary of State in exercising public health functions (as defined by section 1H of that Act),
the priorities that the National Health Service Commissioning Board has for the provision of health services,
documents published by the Secretary of State under section 90(1), (2) or (3),
the desirability of promoting the integration of health provision with health-related provision and care and support provision,
the desirability of enabling health care workers to switch between different posts relating to health provision, health-related provision or care and support provision, and
such other matters as regulations may specify.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1), “health provision”, “health-related provision” and “care and support provision” each have the same meaning as in section 3.

HEE must make arrangements for obtaining advice on the exercise of its functions from persons who are involved in, or who HEE thinks otherwise have an interest in, the provision of education and training for health care workers.
HEE must seek to ensure that it receives representations from the following, in particular, under the arrangements it makes under subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: persons who provide health services;
persons to whom health services are provided;
carers for persons to whom health services are provided;
health care workers;
bodies which regulate health care workers;
persons who provide, or contribute to the provision of, education and training for health care workers.

P2para.Text: HEE may perform a duty under subsection (2) by seeking to ensure that it receives representations from organisations which represent the persons referred to in the paragraph in question.

HEE must advise the Secretary of State on such matters relating to its functions as the Secretary of State may request; and a request under this subsection may specify how and when the advice is to be provided.
“Carer” means an adult who provides or intends to provide care for another person.

HEE must, in exercise of the power under paragraph 9 of Schedule 5, appoint committees for areas in England, each of which is to be called a Local Education and Training Board (referred to in this Chapter as an “LETB”).
The main function of an LETB is to exercise on HEE’s behalf its functions under sections 87(1) and 88(1) (planning and delivering education for health care
workers and ensuring sufficient skilled health care workers in the health service), so far as they are exercisable in or in relation to the LETB’s area.
In carrying out its main function, an LETB must represent the interests of all the persons who provide health services in the area for which the LETB is appointed.
An LETB may co-operate with another LETB in the exercise of functions; and two or more LETBs may exercise functions jointly.
HEE may attend any meeting held by an LETB about a matter of concern to HEE.

Where, on an application under this section, HEE is satisfied that the applicants meet the criteria that HEE has set for the purpose (the “appointment criteria”), HEE must appoint the applicants as members of an LETB for such area as HEE considers appropriate.

Where, on an application under this section, HEE is satisfied that the applicants meet some (but not all) of the appointment criteria, it may nonetheless appoint the applicants as the members of an LETB for such area and subject to such conditions as HEE considers appropriate.
The members of an LETB must include—

P3para.Text: persons who provide health services in the area for which the LETB is appointed, and
persons who have clinical expertise of a description specified in regulations.

P2para.Text: The regulations may require a specified number of members to have that expertise.
The following persons are also eligible to be appointed as members of an LETB—

P3para.Text: persons who, in the area for which the LETB is appointed, provide education or training for health care workers or for persons wishing to work as health care workers, and
persons of such other description as HEE may decide.

P2para.Text: A member of HEE is not eligible for membership of an LETB.

The appointment criteria must include criteria designed to ensure that a majority of the members of an LETB are persons who provide health services in the area for which the LETB in question is appointed.

If HEE is unable (for reasons beyond its control) to comply with any requirement imposed by this section or regulations under this section to appoint persons of a particular description as members of an LETB, HEE may instead appoint employees of HEE (other than members of HEE).
On appointing an LETB, HEE must appoint the chair of the LETB; but it may not appoint as chair a person who—

P3para.Text: provides health services in the area for which the LETB is appointed, or
in the area for which the LETB is appointed, provides education or training for health care workers or for persons wishing to work as health care workers.

P2para.Text: HEE must notify applicants under subsection (1) or (2) of the decision on the application and—

P3para.Text: in the case of an approval of such an application, the area for which the LETB is appointed and the appointment under subsection (9);
in the case of a rejection, the reasons for the rejection.

P2para.Text: HEE, having complied with subsection (10), must publish—

P3para.Text: the decision, and
in the case of a rejection, the reasons for the rejection.

P2para.Text: The conditions on which a person is appointed as a member of an LETB must include a condition not to use information obtained in the capacity as such otherwise than for the purposes of the LETB.
Regulations may make further provision about—

P3para.Text: the membership of an LETB;
the removal by HEE of members of an LETB;
the suspension by HEE of members of an LETB.

P2para.Text: Schedule 6 (which includes provision about the area of an LETB, the appointment criteria and the exercise of an LETB’s functions) has effect.

P1group.Title: LETBs: co-operation by providers of health services

P2para.Text: Regulations must require specified commissioners of health services to include in the arrangements under the National Health Service Act 2006 for the provision of such services terms to ensure that a provider of such services—

P3para.Text: co-operates with the LETB for each area in which it provides such services, in such manner and to such extent as the LETB in question may request, in planning the provision of, and in providing, education and training for health care workers;
provides the LETB in question with such information as it may request;
complies with such other obligations relating to education and training for health care workers as may be specified.

P2para.Text: Duties imposed by regulations under subsection (1) on commissioners of health services are in addition to the duty imposed on such persons by section 1F(2) of the National Health Service Act 2006 (duty to secure that persons providing health services co-operate with the Secretary of State in the discharge of the duty as to education and training).

Regulations may specify factors to which an LETB must, when proposing to make a request of the type mentioned in subsection (1)(a) or (b), have regard in considering the reasonableness of making the request.
A reference to a commissioner of health services is a reference to—

P3para.Text: the National Health Service Commissioning Board,
a clinical commissioning group, or
such other person as arranges for the provision of such services.

P2para.Text: An LETB must publish for each financial year a document (called an “education and training plan”) specifying how it proposes to exercise its main function (see section 93(2)).
The education and training plan of an LETB must specify how the LETB proposes to—

P3para.Text: achieve the objectives and reflect the priorities set by the Secretary of State for the purposes of section 90(1),
achieve the objectives and reflect the priorities set by HEE for the purposes of section 90(4)(a),
achieve the outcomes set by the Secretary of State for the purposes of section 90(2), and
achieve the outcomes set by HEE for the purposes of section 90(4)(b).

P2para.Text: In preparing its education and training plan, an LETB must have regard to—

P3para.Text: the priorities that the providers of health services whom the LETB represents have in relation to the provision in the LETB’s area of health services and of education and training for health care workers or persons wishing to become health care workers,
the priorities that commissioners of health services in the LETB’s area have in relation to those matters,
any assessment of relevant needs relating to the LETB’s area prepared under section 116 of the Local Government and Public Involvement in Health Act 2007,
any joint health and wellbeing strategy relating to the LETB’s area prepared under section 116A of that Act, and
the LETB’s objectives in the longer term in relation to the exercise of the LETB’s main function.

P2para.Text: In preparing its education and training plan, an LETB must involve—

P3para.Text: the providers of health services whom the LETB represents,
the commissioners of health services in the LETB’s area,
the Health and Wellbeing Board for that area,
such persons as HEE may direct the LETB to involve, and
such other persons as the LETB considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: Before publishing its education and training plan (or an amended education and training plan), an LETB must obtain approval of the plan (or the amended plan) from HEE.
Before giving an approval under subsection (5), HEE may direct the LETB concerned to amend the education and training plan (or the amended education and training plan) as HEE specifies.

But, in the case of an LETB which meets all the appointment criteria, the only amendments which HEE may direct to be made under subsection (6) are those HEE considers necessary in order to ensure that the LETB achieves the outcomes set by HEE for the purposes of section 90(4)(b).
Where HEE exercises the power under subsection (6), it must publish—

P3para.Text: the amendments in question, and
its reasons for directing them to be made.

P2para.Text: HEE may give LETBs directions about—

P3para.Text: what to include in their education and training plans;
how to present them.

P2para.Text: An LETB may perform the duty under subsection (1) by preparing two or more documents which, taken together, specify how it proposes to exercise its main function.
Each LETB must for each financial year arrange for the provision of education and training in accordance with its education and training plan for that year.
Where HEE considers that it would be better for the arrangements for the provision of certain education and training to be made on a national basis, it—

P3para.Text: may arrange for the provision of that education and training accordingly, or
may direct one or more LETBs to do so on its behalf.

P2para.Text: Before exercising a power under subsection (2), HEE must involve LETBs in making its decision.
HEE must for each financial year allocate to each LETB the amount that HEE considers appropriate to enable the LETB to comply with this section.

In doing so, HEE must take into account any duty to which the LETB is subject under section 98(9) (requirement to make payments by reference to an approved tariff price or a price varied under a specified procedure).

An LETB may arrange for another person to help it to exercise the function under subsection (1) or (where it is directed to do so under subsection (2)(b)) the function under subsection (2)(a) (and such functions as are exercisable for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of the function concerned).
Each LETB—

P3para.Text: must keep under review the quality of the education and training the provision of which it arranges, and
must report its findings to such persons as it considers may be interested by them.

P2para.Text: An LETB must produce such reports on the exercise of the function under subsection (1) (including on the quality of the education and training the provision of which it arranges) as HEE may require.
The Secretary of State may specify a tariff setting approved prices in respect of education and training.
The approved prices may be different for different descriptions of education and training (and may in particular be different for different areas).
A tariff specified under subsection (1) must be published.
If a tariff is specified under subsection (1), the Secretary of State may also specify a procedure for varying the approved prices in particular cases or descriptions of cases.
If the Secretary of State does so, the procedure—

P3para.Text: must be published, and
must require a price as varied under the procedure to be published.

P2para.Text: A published tariff or variation procedure may be revised or revoked by the Secretary of State.
If a tariff or variation procedure is revised, the Secretary of State must publish it as revised.
If it is revoked, the Secretary of State must publish a statement to that effect.

Where a tariff sets an approved price for a particular description of education or training, payments made by an LETB or HEE in respect of the provision of that description of education or training must be made—

P3para.Text: by reference to the approved price, or
where the approved price has been varied in accordance with a variation procedure that has effect in relation to it, by reference to the price as varied.

P2para.Text: There is to be a body corporate called the Health Research Authority (referred to in this Act as “the HRA”).
Schedule 7 (which includes provision about the HRA’s constitution, the exercise of its functions and its financial and reporting duties) has effect.
The Special Health Authority called the Health Research Authority is abolished; and, in consequence of that, the following are revoked—

P3para.Text: the Health Research Authority (Establishment and Constitution) Order 2011 (S.I. 2011/2323), and
the Health Research Authority Regulations 2011 (S.I. 2011/2341).

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order provide for the transfer of property, rights and liabilities from that Special Health Authority to the HRA; for further provision about an order under this section, see section 108.
The main functions of the HRA are—

P3para.Text: functions relating to the co-ordination and standardisation of practice relating to the regulation of health and social care research (see section 101);
functions relating to research ethics committees (see sections 102 to 105);
functions as a member of the United Kingdom Ethics Committee Authority (see section 106 and the Medicines for Human Use (Clinical Trials) Regulations 2004 (S.I. 2004/1031));

functions relating to approvals for processing confidential information relating to patients (see section 107 and the Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002 (S.I. 2002/1438)).

P2para.Text: The main objective of the HRA in exercising its functions is—

P3para.Text: to protect participants and potential participants in health or social care research and the general public by encouraging research that is safe and ethical, and
to promote the interests of those participants and potential participants and the general public by facilitating the conduct of such research.

P2para.Text: Health research is research into matters relating to people’s physical or mental health; but a reference to health research does not include a reference to anything authorised under the Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act 1986.

Social care research is research into matters relating to personal care or other practical assistance for individuals in need of care or assistance because of age, physical or mental illness, disability, pregnancy, childbirth, dependence on alcohol or drugs or other similar circumstances; and “illness” has the meaning given by section 275(1) of the National Health Service Act 2006.
A reference to health or social care research does not include a reference to research into matters which are within the legislative competence of a devolved legislature.
A reference to research that is ethical is a reference to research that conforms to generally accepted ethical standards.
The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (1) in consequence of—

P3para.Text: functions being given to the HRA,
functions being taken away from the HRA, or
changes to the description of functions that the HRA has for the time being.

P1group.Title: Co-ordinating and promoting regulatory practice etc.

P2para.Text: The HRA and each of the following must co-operate with each other in the exercise of their respective functions relating to health or social care research, with a view to co-ordinating and standardising practice relating to the regulation of such research—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State;
the licensing authority for the purposes of the Medicines Act 1968;
the Health and Social Care Information Centre;
the Chief Medical Officer of the Department of Health;
the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority;
the Human Tissue Authority;
the Care Quality Commission;
the Administration of Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee;
such person, or a person of such description, as regulations may specify.

P2para.Text: In performing the duty under subsection (1), a person must have regard to the need—

P3para.Text: to protect participants and potential participants in health or social care research and the general public by encouraging research that is safe and ethical, and
to promote the interests of those participants and potential participants and the general public by facilitating the conduct of such research.

P2para.Text: The HRA must promote the co-ordination and standardisation of practice in the United Kingdom relating to the regulation of health and social care research; and it must, in doing so, seek to ensure that such regulation is proportionate.

The HRA and each devolved authority must co-operate with each other in the exercise of their respective functions relating to the regulation of assessments of the ethics of health and social care research, with a view to co-ordinating and standardising practice in the United Kingdom relating to such regulation.
The HRA must—

P3para.Text: keep under review matters relating to the ethics of health or social care research and matters relating to the regulation of such research, and
provide the Secretary of State with such advice about the matters referred to in paragraph (a) as the Secretary of State requests.

P2para.Text: The HRA must publish guidance on—

P3para.Text: principles of good practice in the management and conduct of health and social care research;
requirements, whether imposed by enactments or otherwise, to which persons conducting health or social care research are subject.

P2para.Text: A local authority (within the meaning of Part 1), an NHS trust established under section 25 of the National Health Service Act 2006 and an NHS foundation trust must each have regard to guidance under subsection (6).
The ways in which persons may co-operate with each other under subsection (1) or (4) include, for example, by sharing information.

Section 290 of the Health and Social Care Act 2012 (duties for health and social care authorities to co-operate), so far as applying to a person who is for the time being within subsection (1), does not apply to functions of that person relating to health or social care research.
Section 100(5) (exclusion of research into matters within devolved competence) does not apply to the reference in subsection (1) or (4) to health and social care research.

P1group.Title: The HRA’s policy on research ethics committees

P2para.Text: The HRA must ensure that research ethics committees it recognises or establishes under this Chapter provide an efficient and effective means of assessing the ethics of health and social care research.

A research ethics committee is a group of persons which assesses the ethics of research involving individuals; and the ways in which health or social care research might involve individuals include, for example—

P3para.Text: by obtaining information from them;
by obtaining bodily tissue or fluid from them;
by using information, tissue or fluid obtained from them on a previous occasion;
by requiring them to undergo a test or other process (including xenotransplantation).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1), the HRA—

P3para.Text: must publish a document (called “the REC policy document”) which specifies the requirements which it expects research ethics committees it recognises or establishes under this Chapter to comply with, and
must monitor their compliance with those requirements.

P2para.Text: The HRA may do such other things in relation to research ethics committees it recognises or establishes under this Chapter as it considers appropriate; it may, for example—

P3para.Text: co-ordinate their work;
allocate work to them;
develop and maintain training programmes designed to ensure that their members and staff can carry out their work effectively;
provide them with advice and help (including help in the form of financial assistance).

P2para.Text: The requirements in the REC policy document may, for example, relate to—

P3para.Text: membership;
proceedings;
staff;
accommodation and facilities;
expenses;
objectives and functions;
accountability;
procedures for challenging decisions.

P2para.Text: The HRA must ensure that the requirements imposed on research ethics committees in the REC policy document do not conflict with the requirements imposed on them by the Medicines for Human Use (Clinical Trials) Regulations 2004 (S.I. 2004/1031).
Before publishing the REC policy document, the HRA must consult—

P3para.Text: the devolved authorities, and
such other persons as it considers appropriate.

P2para.Text: The HRA may revise the REC policy document and, where it does so, it must publish the document as revised; subsection (7) applies to a revised policy document in so far as the HRA considers the revisions significant.

The HRA must indemnify the members of each research ethics committee it recognises or establishes under this Chapter against any liability to a third party for loss, damage or injury arising from the committee’s exercise of its functions in assessing the ethics of health or social care research.
The HRA must publish guidance about—

P3para.Text: the cases in which, in its opinion, good practice requires a person proposing to conduct health or social care research that involves individuals to obtain the approval of a research ethics committee recognised or established by the HRA under this Chapter, and
the cases in which an enactment requires a person proposing to conduct research of that kind to obtain that approval.

P2para.Text: Before publishing guidance under subsection (1), the HRA must—

P3para.Text: consult the devolved authorities and such other persons as the HRA considers appropriate, and
obtain the approval of the Secretary of State.

P2para.Text: The HRA may revise guidance under subsection (1) and, where it does so, it must publish the guidance as revised; subsection (2) applies to revised guidance in so far as the HRA considers the revisions significant.
Schedule 8 (which amends various references to research ethics committees in secondary legislation) has effect.
The HRA may, on an application made by or on behalf of a group of persons, recognise the group as a research ethics committee which is capable of—

P3para.Text: approving research of the kind referred to in section 103(1), and
giving such other approvals as enactments require.

P2para.Text: The HRA may not recognise a group under this section unless it is satisfied that—

P3para.Text: the group will, if recognised, comply with the requirements set out in the REC policy document, and
there is or will be a demand for such a group.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to recognise a group under this section, the HRA must have regard to whether the group is recognised as a research ethics committee by or on behalf of a devolved authority.

The HRA may do anything (including providing financial assistance) to help a group wishing to be recognised under this section to reach a position from which it should be able to make an application for recognition under this section that is likely to succeed.
The HRA may revoke a recognition under this section if it is satisfied that—

P3para.Text: the group to which the recognition applies is not complying with the requirements specified in the REC policy document,
the group is not (or is not properly) carrying out its function of assessing the ethical aspects of research, or
revocation is necessary or desirable for some other reason.

P2para.Text: A group in existence immediately before the commencement of section 99, and established or recognised by or on behalf of the old Health Research Authority, or by or on behalf of the Secretary of State, as a research ethics committee which assesses health or social care research is to be regarded as recognised by the HRA under this section.
The reference in subsection (6) to the old Health Research Authority is a reference to the Special Health Authority called the Health Research Authority (and abolished by section 99).
The HRA may establish research ethics committees which have the following functions—

P3para.Text: approving research of the kind referred to in section 103(1);
giving such other approvals as enactments require.

P2para.Text: The HRA must ensure that a research ethics committee established under this section complies with the requirements set out in the REC policy document.
The HRA may abolish a research ethics committee established under this section.

P1group.Title: Membership of the United Kingdom Ethics Committee Authority

P1para.Text: In regulation 5 of the Medicines for Human Use (Clinical Trials) Regulations 2004 (S.I. 2004/1031) (United Kingdom Ethics Committee Authority)—

P3para.Text: in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3), for “the Secretary of State for Health”, in each place it appears, substitute “the Health Research Authority”, and
in paragraph (2), for “the Secretary of State” substitute “the Health Research Authority”.

P1group.Title: Approval for processing confidential patient information

P2para.Text: The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002 (S.I. 2002/1438) are amended as follows.
In regulation 5 (the title to which becomes “Approval for processing information”)—

P3para.Text: the existing text becomes paragraph (1), and
in sub-paragraph (a) of that paragraph, for “both the Secretary of State and a research ethics committee” substitute “the Health Research Authority”.

P2para.Text: After paragraph (1) of that regulation insert—
The Health Research Authority may not give an approval under paragraph (1)(a) unless a research ethics committee has approved the medical research concerned.
After paragraph (2) of that regulation insert—
The Health Research Authority shall put in place and operate a system for reviewing decisions it makes under paragraph (1)(a).
In regulation 6 (registration requirements in relation to information), in paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: before “the Secretary of State” insert “the Health Research Authority or”, and
before “he” insert “it or”.

P2para.Text: In paragraph (2)(d) of that regulation, before “the Secretary of State” insert “the Health Research Authority or (as the case may be)”.

In paragraph (3) of that regulation, for the words from the beginning to “in the register” substitute “The Health Research Authority shall retain the particulars of each entry it records in the register, and the Secretary of State shall retain the particulars of each entry he records in the register,”.
For paragraph (4) of that regulation substitute—

The Health Research Authority shall, in such manner and to such extent as it considers appropriate, publish entries it records in the register; and the Secretary of State shall, in such manner and to such extent as he considers appropriate, publish entries he records in the register.

An order under section 86 (establishment of Health Education England) or section 99 (establishment of the Health Research Authority) (a “transfer order”) may make provision for rights and liabilities relating to an individual’s contract of employment.
A transfer order may, in particular, make provision the same as or similar to provision in the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (S.I. 2006/246).
A transfer order may provide for the transfer of property, rights or liabilities—

P3para.Text: whether or not they would otherwise be capable of being transferred;
irrespective of any requirement for consent that would otherwise apply.

P2para.Text: A transfer order may create rights, or impose liabilities, in relation to property, rights or liabilities transferred.
A transfer order may provide for things done by or in relation to the transferor for the purposes of or in connection with anything transferred to be—

P3para.Text: treated as done by or in relation to the transferee or its employees;
continued by or in relation to the transferee or its employees.

P2para.Text: A transfer order may in particular make provision about continuation of legal proceedings.
For the purposes of this Part, an expression in the first column of the following table is defined or otherwise explained by the provision of this Act specified in the second column.
A power under this Part to give a direction—

P3para.Text: includes a power to vary or revoke the direction by a subsequent direction, and
must be exercised by giving the direction in question in writing.

P2para.Text: The amendments made by sections 106 and 107 and Schedule 8 to provisions of subordinate legislation do not affect the power to make further subordinate legislation amending or revoking the amended provisions.
The Secretary of State may by order make provision in consequence of a provision of this Act.
An order under this section may amend, repeal, revoke or otherwise modify an enactment.
The power conferred by this section is not restricted by any other provision of this Act.

A saving or a transitional or transitory provision in an order under this section by virtue of section 112(7) may, in particular, modify the application of a provision made by the order pending the commencement of—

P3para.Text: another provision of the order,
a provision of this Act, or
any other enactment.

P2para.Text: Before making an order under this section that contains provision which is within the legislative competence of a devolved legislature, the Secretary of State must consult the relevant devolved authority.
A reference to an enactment includes a reference to an enactment passed or made after the passing of this Act.

P1group.Title: Power to make transitional etc. provision

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order make transitional, transitory or saving provision in connection with the commencement of a provision of this Act.
An order under this section may modify the application of a provision of this Act pending the commencement of—

P3para.Text: another provision of this Act, or
any other enactment (including one passed or made after the passing of this Act).

P2para.Text: A power or duty to make regulations under this Act is exercisable by the Secretary of State.
Regulations and orders under this Act must be made by statutory instrument.
Subject to subsections (4) and (5), a statutory instrument containing regulations or an order under this Act is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

A statutory instrument which contains (whether alone or with other provision) any of the following may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament—

P3para.Text: regulations under section 13(7) (the eligibility criteria);
regulations under section 15(4) (the cap on care costs) other than those made in discharge of the duty under section 16(1);
the first regulations under section 15(8) (the amount attributable to an adult’s daily living costs);
regulations under section 22(2)(b) (services or facilities which a local authority may not provide or arrange);

regulations under section 35(9) or 36(3) (deferred payment agreements and loans and alternative financial arrangements) which include provision that amends or repeals a provision of an Act of Parliament;
the first regulations under section 52(12) (meaning of references to business failure);
the first regulations under section 53(1) (criteria for application of market oversight regime);
the first regulations under section 53(4) (disapplication of market oversight regime in particular cases);
the first regulations under section 62(2) (exercise of power to meet child’s carer’s needs for support);
an order under section 75(9) (delegation of local authority functions);
regulations under section 84 (offence of supplying etc false or misleading information);
an order under section 110 (consequential provision) which includes provision that amends or repeals a provision of an Act of Parliament;
regulations under paragraph 17 of Schedule 7 (fees chargeable by the HRA).

P2para.Text: Subsection (3) does not apply to—

P3para.Text: an order under section 86 (transfer order to new HEE);
an order under section 99 (transfer order to new HRA);
an order under section 111 (transitional etc. provision);
an order under section 114 (commencement).

P2para.Text: A power to make regulations or an order under this Act—

P3para.Text: may be exercised for all cases to which the power applies, for those cases subject to specified exceptions, or for any specified cases or descriptions of case,
may be exercised so as to make, for the cases for which it is exercised—

P4para.Text: the full provision to which the power applies or any less provision (whether by way of exception or otherwise);

the same provision for all cases for which the power is exercised, or different provision for different cases or different descriptions of case, or different provision as respects the same case or description of case for different purposes of this Act;
any such provision either unconditionally or subject to specified conditions, and

P3para.Text: may, in particular, make different provision for different areas.

P2para.Text: A power to make regulations or an order under this Act (other than the power to make an order under section 111 or 114) includes —

P3para.Text: power to make incidental, supplementary, consequential, saving, transitional or transitory provision, and
power to provide for a person to exercise a discretion in dealing with a matter.

P2para.Text: Before making regulations under section 52(12) (meaning of references to business failure), the Secretary of State must consult the Welsh Ministers and the Department for Health, Social Services and Public Safety in Northern Ireland.

P1para.Text: In this Act—

Para.Text: “devolved authority” means the Scottish Ministers, the Welsh Ministers or the Department for Health, Social Services and Public Safety in Northern Ireland,
“devolved legislature” means the Scottish Parliament, the National Assembly for Wales or the Northern Ireland Assembly,
“enactment” includes—
an enactment contained in subordinate legislation (within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978), and
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish Parliament, an Act or Measure of the National Assembly for Wales or Northern Ireland legislation,

“financial year” means a period of 12 months ending with 31 March (but see also the definition of that expression in paragraph 3 of Schedule 2, paragraph 19 of Schedule 5 and paragraph 18 of Schedule 7), and
“the health service” means the comprehensive health service in England continued under section 1(1) of the National Health Service Act 2006.

P2para.Text: The provisions of Parts 1 to 3 come into force on such day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint.
The provisions of this Part come into force on the day on which this Act is passed.

Before making an order under this section bringing section 50 (provider failure: temporary duty on local authority in Wales in cross-border cases) into force, the Secretary of State must obtain the consent of the Welsh Ministers.

Before making an order under this section bringing section 51 (provider failure: temporary duty on Health and Social Care trusts in cross-border cases) into force, the Secretary of State must obtain the consent of the Department for Health, Social Services and Public Safety in Northern Ireland.
Different days may be appointed under subsection (1) for different purposes (including different areas).
This Act extends to England and Wales only, subject to subsections (2) and (3).

Any amendment, repeal or revocation made by this Act has the same extent as the enactment being amended, repealed or revoked, other than the amendment made by section 66(3) which extends to England and Wales only.
The following also extend to Scotland and Northern Ireland—

P3para.Text: section 39(7) and Schedule 1 (cross-border placements);
sections 49 to 52 (provider failure: temporary duty in relation to cross-border cases);
Chapter 2 of Part 3 (the HRA);
section 108 (transfer orders), so far as relating to section 99 (the HRA);
section 109 (Part 3: interpretation and supplementary provision);
this Part;
paragraph 17 of Schedule 5 (arrangements between HEE and devolved authorities) and section 86(2) so far as relating to that paragraph.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order provide that specified provisions of this Act, in their application to the Isles of Scilly, have effect with such modifications as may be specified.

P1para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Care Act 2013.

P1group.Title: Placements from England to Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in England is meeting an adult’s needs for care and support by arranging for the provision of accommodation in Wales, the adult—

P3para.Text: is to be treated for the purposes of this Part as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and
is accordingly not to be treated for the purposes of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 as ordinarily resident anywhere in Wales.

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in England, in reliance on section 22(4), is making arrangements which include the provision of accommodation in Wales, section 22(4) is to have effect as if for paragraph (a) there were substituted—

P3para.Text: the authority has obtained consent for it to arrange for the provision of the nursing care from the Local Health Board for the area in which the accommodation is provided,

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in England is meeting an adult’s needs for care and support by arranging for the provision of accommodation in Scotland—

P3para.Text: the adult is to be treated for the purposes of this Part as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and
no duty under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 or sections 25 to 27 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in England is meeting an adult’s needs for care and support by arranging for the provision of accommodation in Northern Ireland—

P3para.Text: the adult is to be treated for the purposes of this Part as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and

no duty under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 or the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 to provide or secure the provision of accommodation or other facilities applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: Section 22 (prohibition on provision of health services) is to have effect—

P3para.Text: in its application to a case within sub-paragraph (1)—

P4para.Text: as if the references in subsections (1) and (6) to the National Health Service Act 2006 included a reference to the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006, and
as if the reference in subsection (6) to a clinical commissioning group or the National Health Service Commissioning Board included a reference to a Local Health Board;

P3para.Text: in its application to a case within sub-paragraph (3)—

P4para.Text: as if the references in subsections (1) and (6) to the National Health Service Act 2006 included a reference to the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978, and
as if the reference in subsection (6) to a clinical commissioning group or the National Health Service Commissioning Board included a reference to a Health Board or Special Health Board;

P3para.Text: in its application to a case within sub-paragraph (4)—

P4para.Text: as if the references in subsections (1) and (6) to a service or facility provided under the National Health Service Act 2006 included a reference to health care provided under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 or the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009, and
as if the reference in subsection (6) to a clinical commissioning group or the National Health Service Commissioning Board included a reference to a Health and Social Care trust.

P2para.Text: Regulations may make further provision in relation to arrangements of the kind referred to in this paragraph.

The regulations may specify circumstances in which, in a case within sub-paragraph (3), specified duties under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 are nonetheless to apply in the case of the adult concerned (and paragraph (b) of that sub-paragraph is to be read accordingly).

P1group.Title: Placements from Wales to England, Scotland or Northern Ireland

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Wales is discharging its duty under section 21 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 by arranging for the provision of accommodation in England, the adult concerned—

P3para.Text: is to be treated for the purposes of that Act as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and
is accordingly not to be treated for the purposes of Part 1 of this Act as ordinarily resident anywhere in England.

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Wales is arranging for the provision of accommodation in England in the exercise of its power under section 22 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013—

P3para.Text: the adult concerned is to be treated for the purposes of that Act—

P4para.Text: in a case where the adult was within the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in England, as remaining within that area;
in a case where the adult was outside but ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in
England, as remaining outside but ordinarily resident in that area, and

P3para.Text: the adult concerned is not to be treated for the purposes of Part 1 of this Act as ordinarily resident anywhere in England (unless the adult was so ordinarily resident immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in England).

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Wales is discharging its duty under section 21 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 by arranging for the provision of accommodation in Scotland—

P3para.Text: the adult is to be treated for the purposes of that Act as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and
no duty under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 or sections 25 to 27 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Wales is arranging for the provision of accommodation in Scotland in the exercise of its power under section 22 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013—

P3para.Text: the adult concerned is to be treated for the purposes of that Act—

P4para.Text: in a case where the adult was within the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in Scotland, as remaining within that area;

in a case where the adult was outside but ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in Scotland, as remaining outside but ordinarily resident in that area, and

P3para.Text: no duty under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 or sections 25 to 27 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: But paragraph (b) of sub-paragraph (4) does not prevent a duty mentioned in that paragraph from applying in the case of an adult who was ordinarily resident in Scotland immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in Scotland.
Where a local authority in Wales is discharging its duty under section 21 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 by arranging for the provision of accommodation in Northern Ireland—

P3para.Text: the adult is to be treated for the purposes of that Act as ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area, and

no duty under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 or the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 to provide or secure the provision of accommodation or other facilities applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Wales is arranging for the provision of accommodation in Northern Ireland in the exercise of its power under section 22 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013—

P3para.Text: the adult concerned is to be treated for the purposes of that Act—

P4para.Text: in a case where the adult was within the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority
with accommodation in Northern Ireland, as remaining within that area;

in a case where the adult was outside but ordinarily resident in the local authority’s area immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in Northern Ireland, as remaining outside but ordinarily resident in that area, and

P3para.Text: no duty under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 or the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 to provide or secure the provision of accommodation or other facilities applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: But paragraph (b) of sub-paragraph (7) does not prevent a duty mentioned in that paragraph from applying in the case of an adult who was ordinarily resident in Northern Ireland immediately before being provided by the local authority with accommodation in Northern Ireland.
Regulations may make further provision in relation to arrangements of the kind referred to in this paragraph.

The regulations may specify circumstances in which, in a case within sub-paragraph (3) or (4), specified duties under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 are nonetheless to apply in the case of the adult concerned (and paragraph (b) of each of those sub-paragraphs is to be read accordingly).

P1group.Title: Placements from Scotland to England, Wales or Northern Ireland

P2para.Text: Where a local authority in Scotland is discharging its duty under section 12 or 13A of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 or section 25 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 by securing the provision of accommodation in England, the adult in question is not to be treated for the purposes of Part 1 of this Act as ordinarily resident anywhere in England.

Where a local authority in Scotland is discharging its duty under a provision referred to in sub-paragraph (1) by securing the provision of accommodation in Wales, the adult in question is not to be treated for the purposes of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 as ordinarily resident anywhere in Wales.

Where a local authority in Scotland is discharging its duty under a provision referred to in sub-paragraph (1) by securing the provision of accommodation in Northern Ireland, no duty under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 or the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 to provide or secure the provision of accommodation or other facilities applies in the case of the adult in question.
In section 5 of the Community Care and Health (Scotland) Act 2002 (local authority arrangements for residential accommodation outside Scotland)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), after “the 1968 Act” insert “or under section 25 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 (care and support)”,
in subsection (2), for “such arrangements” substitute “persons for whom such arrangements are made”, and
for subsections (5) and (6) substitute—

P2para.Text: In subsections (1) and (3) above, “appropriate establishment” means an establishment of such description or conforming to such requirements as may be specified in regulations under subsection (1).
Regulations may make further provision in relation to arrangements of the kind referred to in this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Placements from Northern Ireland to England, Wales or Scotland

P2para.Text: Where there are arrangements under Article 15 of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 for the provision of accommodation in England, the adult in question—

P3para.Text: is to be treated for the purposes of that Order and the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 as ordinarily resident in the area of the relevant Health and Social Care trust, and
is accordingly not to be treated for the purposes of Part 1 of this Act as ordinarily resident anywhere in England.

P2para.Text: Where there are arrangements under Article 15 of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 for the provision of accommodation in Wales, the adult in question—

P3para.Text: is to be treated for the purposes of that Order and the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 as ordinarily resident in the area of the relevant Health and Social Care trust, and
is accordingly not to be treated for the purposes of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 as ordinarily resident anywhere in Wales.

P2para.Text: Where there are arrangements under Article 15 of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 for the provision of accommodation in Scotland—

P3para.Text: the adult in question is to be treated for the purposes of that Order and the Health and Social Care (Reform) Act (Northern Ireland) 2009 as ordinarily resident in the area of the relevant Health and Social Care trust, and
no duty under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 or sections 25 to 27 of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003 applies in the adult’s case.

P2para.Text: The reference to the relevant Health and Social Care trust is a reference to the Health and Social Care trust in whose area the adult in question was ordinarily resident immediately before the making of arrangements of the kind referred to in this paragraph.
Regulations may make further provision in relation to arrangements of the kind referred to in this paragraph.

The regulations may specify circumstances in which, in a case within sub-paragraph (3), specified duties under Part 2 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 are nonetheless to apply in the case of the adult concerned (and paragraph (b) of that sub-paragraph is to be read accordingly).
Any dispute about the application of any of paragraphs 1 to 4 to an adult’s case is to be determined in accordance with this paragraph.
If the dispute is between a local authority in England and a local authority in Wales, it is to be determined by the Secretary of State or the Welsh Ministers.
If the dispute is between a local authority in England and a local authority in Scotland, it is to be determined by the Secretary of State or the Scottish Ministers.
If the dispute is between a local authority in England and a Health and Social Care trust, it is to be determined by the Secretary of State or the Northern Ireland Department.
If the dispute is between a local authority in Wales and a local authority in Scotland, it is to be determined by the Welsh Ministers or the Scottish Ministers.
If the dispute is between a local authority in Wales and a Health and Social Care trust, it is to be determined by the Welsh Ministers or the Northern Ireland Department.
If the dispute is between a local authority in Scotland and a Health and Social Care trust, it is to be determined by the Scottish Ministers or the Northern Ireland Department.
In Article 36 of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972, after paragraph (2) insert—
Any question under this Order as to the ordinary residence of a person is to be determined by the Department.

Regulations must make provision for determining which of the persons concerned is to determine the dispute; and the regulations may, in particular, provide for the dispute to be determined by whichever of them agree is to do so.
Regulations may make provision for the determination of disputes between more than two parties.
Regulations may make further provision about determination of disputes under this paragraph or under regulations under sub-paragraph (10); the regulations may, for example, include—

P3para.Text: provision requiring parties to a dispute to take specified steps before referring the dispute for determination under this paragraph;
provision about the procedure for referring the dispute under this paragraph.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: an adult has been provided with accommodation in England, Wales, Scotland or Northern Ireland in a case within any of paragraphs 1 to 4, and

it transpires (whether following the determination of a dispute under paragraph 5 or otherwise) that an authority in another of the territories was, for some or all of the time that the accommodation was being provided, liable to provide the adult with accommodation.

P2para.Text: The authority which made the arrangements may recover from the authority in the other territory the amount of any payments it made towards the making of the arrangements at a time when the other authority was liable to provide the adult with accommodation.
A reference to an authority is a reference to a local authority in England, Wales or Scotland or a Health and Social Care trust in Northern Ireland.

In section 86 of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968 (adjustments between authorities providing accommodation), in subsections (1) and (10), after “a local authority in England or Wales” insert “and to a Health and Social Care trust in Northern Ireland”.

In subsection (2) of that section, after “the ordinary residence of a person shall” insert “, in a case within any of paragraphs 1 to 4 of Schedule 1 to the Care Act 2013 (cross-border placements), be determined in accordance with paragraph 5 of that Schedule; and in any other case, the question shall”.
In section 97 of that Act (extent)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), for “sections 86 and 87” substitute “section 87”, and
after that subsection insert—

P2para.Text: Section 86 of this Act shall extend to England and Wales and to Northern Ireland.

P1para.Text: Regulations under this Schedule—

P3para.Text: if they include provision relating to Wales, may not be made without the consent of the Welsh Ministers;
if they include provision relating to Scotland, may not be made without the consent of the Scottish Ministers;
if they include provision relating to Northern Ireland, may not be made without the consent of the Northern Ireland Department.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies for the purposes of this Schedule.
“Accommodation in England” means accommodation in England of a type specified in regulations under section 39 but not of a type specified in regulations under this paragraph.

“Accommodation in Wales” means accommodation in Wales of a type specified in regulations under section 163 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 but not of a type specified in regulations under this paragraph.

“Accommodation in Scotland” means residential accommodation in Scotland of a type which may be provided under or by virtue of section 12 or 13A of the Social Work (Scotland) Act 1968, or section 25 of the Mental
Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003, but not of a type specified in regulations under this paragraph.

“Accommodation in Northern Ireland” means residential or other accommodation in Northern Ireland of a type which may be provided under Article 15 of the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972.
“Local authority in England” means a local authority for the purposes of this Part.
“Local authority in Wales” means a local authority for the purposes of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013.
“Local authority in Scotland” means a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc. (Scotland) Act 1994.
“The Northern Ireland Department” means the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety in Northern Ireland.

P1para.Text: In section 163 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2013 (ordinary residence), at the end insert—

P2para.Text: For provision about cross-border placements to and from England, Scotland or Northern Ireland, see Schedule 1 to the Care Act 2013.
